data.title: Firefighters prepare for hot, dry conditions as Park Fire reaches over 420K acres
data.meta_description: THE LATEST PARK FIRE INFORMATION AND EVACUATION UPDATES: Containment remains as largest fire in the country burns over 420k acres in CaliforniaThe Park Fire con
data.text:
THE LATEST PARK FIRE INFORMATION AND EVACUATION UPDATES:

The Park Fire continues to burn even as firefighters have increased containment of the blaze that's now the largest burning in the United States. The Park Fire now sits at 420,692 acres and is 34% contained, according to Tuesday.

There were concerns over the weekend about thunderstorms and dry lightning, but luckily, there were no new fires ignited as a result of the weather. Fire officials said temperatures warmed up and the air cleared over the Park Fire leading to more fire activity. Single and group tree torching, short range spotting, and short runs persisted throughout Sunday afternoon.

Temperatures are expected to remain warm at night over the next several nights and the region will be very warm and dry in the coming days.Daytime highs will reach the lower 100s and the minimum relative humidity will range from 10 to 20%.Warm overnight temperatures with below-average humidity will allow heavy fuels to burn actively. Lighter and live fuels may not burn as readily overnight but are expected to rebound quickly during the day.

Firefighters continue building contingency lines in Butte, Shasta, and Tehama counties, officials said.

Fire officials said Monday their damage inspection teams have completed their assessments. Between both Butte and Tehama counties, 640 structures were destroyed and 52 were damaged. A total of 882 structures were saved by firefighters in Butte County, and another 277 in Tehama County.

The Park Fire is currently the largest wildfire burning in the U.S., and the 4th largest fire in California's history. Multiple out-of-state resources and members of the National Guard came to help in the firefight over the weekend.

The fire ignited in Upper Bidwell Park, northeast of Chico, at around 3 p.m. on July 24. The man was allegedly seen pushing a car that was on fire into a gully at Alligator Hole, where the fire started, officials said.
